Dictionary.Name: The Free On-line Dictionary of Computing (27 SEP 03)

Definition.WordDefinition:
thud
1. Yet another {metasyntactic variable} (see {foo}). It is reported that at {CMU} from the mid-1970s the canonical series of these was "foo", "bar", "thud", "blat".
2. Rare term for the hash character, "#" (ASCII 35). See {ASCII} for other synonyms.
[{Jargon File}]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Thud \Thud\ (th[u^]d), n. [Cf. AS. [thorn][=o]den a whirlwind, violent wind, or E. thump.] A dull sound without resonance, like that produced by striking with, or striking against, some comparatively soft substance; also, the stroke or blow producing such sound; as, the thrud of a cannon ball striking the earth. [1913 Webster]
At every new thud of the blast, a sob arose. --Jeffrey. [1913 Webster]
At intervals there came some tremendous thud on the side of the steamer. --C. Mackay. [1913 Webster] [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Thud \Thud\ (th[u^]d), v. i. & t. To make, or strike so as to make, a dull sound, or thud.
Hardly the softest thudding of velvety pads. --A. C. Doyle.
The waves break into spray, dash and rumble and thud below your feet. --H. F. Brown. [Webster 1913 Suppl.] [1913 Webster]

thud n. 1. Yet another {metasyntactic variable} (see {foo}). It is reported that at CMU from the mid-1970s the canonical series of these was `foo', `bar', `thud', `blat'. 2. Rare term for the hash character, `#' (ASCII 0100011). See {ASCII} for other synonyms.

thud n : a heavy dull sound (as made by impact of heavy objects) [syn: {thump}, {thumping}, {clump}, {clunk}] v 1: make a dull sound; "the knocker thudded against the front door" [syn: {thump}] 2: strike with a dull sound; "Bullets were thudding against the wall" 3: make a noise typical of an engine lacking lubricants [syn: {crump}, {scrunch}] [also: {thudding}, {thudded}]
